text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's Austrian newspapers:
- Chamber of Economy is planning to reform Austria's professional licensing system, as it has been heavily criticised in the past for being too complicated.
- Introduction of the European Union's single currency Euro will cost Austria's banks up to eight billion schillings.
- Car engineer Steyr-Daimler-Puch plans to enlarge the firm's R&D units.

- Even though the Austrian electricity industry posted pre-tax profits up 1.4 billion schillings to 4.5 billion schillings last year, liberalisation of the industry in the near future may bring about a rash of insolvencies.
- Conservative People's party is against the Social Democrats' proposition of imposing taxes on national health contributions.
- Austria will have to work hard to reduce the country's deficit in order to make it into the European Monetary Union, the EU Commission said.
- Austria to target Japan with a huge advertising campaign in a bid to gain more tourists.
- Bank Austria will take over German bank WestLB's Austrian subsidiary WestLB Austria through a share swap.
- Upper Austria's Hypo Landesbank will most probably be sold to Raiffeisen bank. The sale is expected to be announced today.
